comments.body:
Starring is (hopefully ;) ) a one-time action. Also, calling it that way seems both manipulative and misleading (not to mention desperate ;P ). 

`See Metals/Bloop on GitHub` is what people would want to do much more often than starring it. And if someone will want to start it then hopefully he would also want to take a look around some issues, pull requests and feature requests to know what to expect in the future.

I think it's fine, I don't think that is in any way manipulative and misleading. From my point of view, I also don't consider this to be a desperate action; starring a project is the least way of recognizing the time and effort put by the developers into creating software *for free*. I think it's fair to ask for it.

Oh, I agree on the whole recognition through starring point - but that is not what I am picking on here.

I am just articulating my thoughts on the *name of the command* which is *constantly shown to the user* (even to one who have already starred it). 
In no way I am condemning the starring of a project. I am not saying "never ever ask for starts". I say - "here, in this place, it may not be always a relevant name". Nothing more, nothing less. 

If you think it is a good place to do so, then that is fine by me. I just believe that "See Metals on github" is relevant any time, while "Start Metals on github" is relevant only until you have actually starred it.

> If you think it is a good place to do so, then that is fine by me. I just believe that "See Metals on github" is relevant any time, while "Start Metals on github" is relevant only until you have actually starred it.

Fair point, but putting "Star Metals on GitHub" as an action that people read will actually force them to realize "Hey, I use this a lot, maybe I should star it", whereas putting "See Metals on GitHub" will definitely not provoke that reaction.
  
I think letting people know there's a clear, visible way of giving recognition to a project they enjoy is benefitial for maintainers and helps create a virtous cycle and attract more users through the GitHub repository.

>I think letting people know there's a clear, visible way of giving recognition

If that is the intention behind this action, then it is more than OK :)

I agree with Marek that staring a repo and following on twitter is a one-time action so it doesn't fit well into the "help and feedback" view. It's better to use the timeless language "Metals on GitHub" and "Scalameta on Twitter". People will infer the actions from those titles instead.

comments.body: We should be able to just pack it into Option? Or is it a gson limitation?

I just followed other params case class declaration, like `MetalsStatusParams`. I would guess, it's a lsp4j limitation, not sure. Maybe @olafurpg  can comment on this ?
Then I do `Option(directory)`, yes.
We're using gson to serialize to JSON and I think you need custom gson adapters to support `Option[T]`
The `@Nullable` annotation isn't required, but I used it to document field where I would have preferred to use `Option[T]`
